body:
The Ultimate Guide to Great Walks: World's Best Hiking Trails & Multi-Day Adventures

Discover the world's most spectacular great walks, from New Zealand's legendary tracks to hidden gems across the globe. After hiking over 50 multi-day trails worldwide, I'm sharing insider tips, essential gear recommendations, and personal experiences to help you plan your next incredible adventure.

← Return to Explore National Parks Store

Table of Contents

  • New Zealand's Legendary Great Walks
  • International Great Walk Destinations
  • Essential Gear for Great Walks
  • My Personal Great Walks Experience
  • Planning & Booking Strategies
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Conclusion

New Zealand's Legendary Great Walks

New Zealand's great walks represent the pinnacle of multi-day hiking experiences, and I've been fortunate to complete eight of the eleven official tracks. These premier trails pass through some of the most spectacular and diverse scenery on Earth, from glacial valleys and ancient forests to pristine coastlines and volcanic landscapes. Each great walk tells a unique story of New Zealand's natural heritage.

The Milford Track, often called the "finest walk in the world," remains the crown jewel among great walks. During my four-day journey through Fiordland, I witnessed waterfalls cascading from towering cliffs after heavy rain transformed the landscape into a living cathedral of water. The track's popularity means booking is competitive – I secured my spot by being online exactly when bookings opened, competing with thousands of other hopeful hikers.

The Routeburn Track offers arguably the most diverse scenery of any great walk. My traverse between Mount Aspiring and Fiordland National Parks revealed alpine lakes, beech forests, and panoramic mountain vistas that changed with every hour of walking. The track's well-maintained condition and relatively moderate difficulty make it ideal for those new to great outdoor adventures.

What sets New Zealand's great walks apart is their infrastructure and management. The Department of Conservation maintains comfortable huts with bunks, cooking facilities, and even flush toilets on most tracks. This level of support allows hikers to focus on the experience rather than survival, making these great walks accessible to anyone with reasonable fitness and proper preparation.

International Great Walk Destinations

Beyond New Zealand's famous tracks, the world offers countless great walks that rival anything found in Aotearoa. My international hiking adventures have taken me to remote corners of six continents, where I've discovered that great walks share certain characteristics: spectacular natural beauty, cultural significance, and the power to transform those who undertake them.

Peru's Inca Trail stands as one of the world's most iconic great walks, combining archaeological wonder with high-altitude Andean scenery. During my four-day trek to Machu Picchu, I learned from local guides about ancient Incan engineering and witnessed sunrise over the lost city – a moment that ranks among my most profound outdoor experiences. The trail's popularity necessitates booking months in advance and limits daily access to just 500 people.

Europe offers remarkable great walks like the Tour du Mont Blanc, which I completed over ten days across France, Italy, and Switzerland. This circumnavigation of Western Europe's highest peak showcases Alpine culture alongside dramatic mountain scenery. The network of mountain refuges provides comfortable accommodation and hearty meals, making this great walk accessible to hikers of varying experience levels.

Australia's Great Ocean Road walk sections reveal rugged coastal beauty, while the Overland Track in Tasmania traverses ancient landscapes unchanged for millennia. Each continent harbors great walks that showcase unique ecosystems and geological formations. From Patagonia's granite spires to Nepal's Himalayan giants, these trails offer transformative experiences for those willing to venture beyond familiar territories.

The key to successful international great walks lies in understanding local conditions, regulations, and cultural expectations. Research permit requirements, seasonal accessibility, and recommended gear lists specific to each destination. Many international great walks require different preparation strategies compared to New Zealand's well-managed tracks.

Essential Gear for Great Walks

After completing dozens of great walks worldwide, I've learned that proper gear makes the difference between magical experiences and miserable struggles. The right equipment doesn't just enhance comfort – it ensures safety and enables you to fully engage with the natural world around you. My gear selections have evolved through trial, error, and countless miles on diverse terrain.

Your backpack serves as your mobile basecamp, carrying everything needed for multi-day adventures. I recommend the Osprey Atmos AG 65 for its exceptional comfort and ventilation system. This pack has accompanied me on great walks from New Zealand's muddy tracks to Peru's high-altitude trails, maintaining comfort even during long days with full loads. The anti-gravity suspension distributes weight effectively, reducing fatigue and allowing focus on the scenery ahead.

Footwear represents your most critical gear investment. Great hiking boots must provide support, comfort, and weather protection across varied terrain. The Salomon Quest 4D 3 GTX boots have proven exceptional across multiple great walks, offering waterproof protection and superior ankle support. Their Contagrip outsole provides reliable traction on both wet rocks and loose soil.

Weather protection systems separate successful great walks from abandoned attempts. The Patagonia Torrentshell 3L Jacket offers reliable waterproof protection without excessive weight or bulk. I've tested this jacket in Fiordland's notorious rainfall and Scotland's driving winds – it maintains breathability while keeping you completely dry.

Navigation and safety equipment should never be overlooked, even on well-marked great walks. Weather can change rapidly, obscuring trails and creating dangerous conditions. Quality outdoor walking boots combined with reliable navigation tools ensure you can handle unexpected situations with confidence and safety.

Essential Gear Checklist

Backpacking Essentials:
  • Quality 50-65L backpack
  • Waterproof rain gear
  • Insulated sleeping system
Navigation & Safety:
  • GPS device or smartphone app
  • First aid kit
  • Emergency shelter

My Personal Great Walks Experience

My journey with great walks began fifteen years ago on New Zealand's Routeburn Track, where I experienced my first multi-day hiking adventure. That initial three-day trek sparked a passion that has since taken me across six continents and countless trails. Each great walk has taught valuable lessons about nature, preparation, and personal resilience that extend far beyond the hiking experience itself.

The most challenging great walk I've completed was Nepal's Everest Base Camp trek, where altitude sickness forced me to reconsider my approach to high-altitude hiking. At 14,000 feet, I learned the importance of gradual acclimatization and listening to my body's signals. This experience fundamentally changed how I prepare for and approach challenging great walks, emphasizing patience over speed and safety over summit fever.

Weather has provided some of my most memorable great walk moments. During my Milford Track journey, unprecedented rainfall closed the track for two days, trapping our group at Mintaro Hut. Rather than disappointment, this became an opportunity to connect with fellow hikers and witness nature's raw power as waterfalls appeared overnight on previously dry cliffs. These unplanned moments often become the most treasured memories from great walks.

My equipment failures have provided costly but valuable lessons. A catastrophic tent failure during Tasmania's Overland Track taught me never to compromise on shelter quality. Similarly, inadequate walking boots during Scotland's West Highland Way resulted in painful blisters that affected my enjoyment for days. These experiences shaped my current gear philosophy: invest in quality items that match your specific needs and intended use.

The social aspect of great walks has surprised me repeatedly. Solo travelers often form lasting friendships with fellow hikers encountered on trails. Some of my closest friendships originated from shared great walk experiences, where challenging conditions and spectacular scenery create strong bonds between strangers. I've learned that great walks offer opportunities for personal growth alongside physical adventure and natural discovery.

Planning & Booking Strategies

Successful great walks require strategic planning that begins months before your departure date. Popular tracks like New Zealand's Milford and Routeburn sell out within minutes of booking opening, requiring military precision and backup plans. I've developed a systematic approach to securing spots on competitive great walks that has proven successful across multiple destinations and seasons.

Timing your booking attempts is crucial for popular great walks. New Zealand's Department of Conservation typically opens bookings in May or June for the following season. I recommend creating calendar reminders, preparing multiple device access points, and having alternative dates ready. The most popular periods – summer weekends and holiday seasons – disappear first, so flexibility with dates dramatically improves your chances of securing accommodation.

Consider shoulder season opportunities for less crowded and often more affordable great walks. My autumn traverse of the Heaphy Track revealed spectacular colors and peaceful trails, while winter attempts at year-round great walks offer unique experiences with proper preparation. However, ensure you research seasonal track conditions and required experience levels before committing to off-season adventures.

Transportation logistics often present the greatest planning challenges for great walks. Many tracks are linear rather than loops, requiring coordination between arrival and departure points. I've learned to book shuttle services simultaneously with accommodation bookings, as popular transfer services fill up alongside the tracks themselves. Car rental and drop-off services provide more flexibility but cost more than shared shuttles.

Physical preparation for great walks should begin months before departure. I recommend gradually increasing your weekly hiking distance and elevation gain while carrying realistic pack weights. Quality trail running shoes can help with training runs, building cardiovascular fitness essential for multi-day adventures. Don't underestimate the importance of mental preparation – great walks require persistence through challenging conditions and weather.

Booking Timeline Strategy

  • 12+ months ahead: Research destinations and create shortlist
  • 6-8 months ahead: Book flights and accommodation
  • 3-4 months ahead: Finalize gear and training plan
  • 1 month ahead: Confirm all bookings and transport

Frequently Asked Questions

What are the New Zealand Great Walks and how do I book them?

New Zealand's Great Walks are 11 premier multi-day hiking tracks through the country's most spectacular scenery, including the famous Milford Track, Routeburn Track, and Abel Tasman Coast Track. Bookings are essential and open in May/June for the following season. The most popular walks like Milford and Routeburn sell out within minutes, so you need to be online exactly when bookings open at 9:30 AM NZ time. Each walk requires advance booking for huts and campsites, with prices ranging from NZ$32-110 per night. I recommend having multiple dates ready and being flexible with your schedule to improve booking success chances.

What gear do I need for great walks?

Essential gear includes a quality 50L hiking backpack, waterproof hiking boots, rain jacket and pants, warm sleeping bag, cooking equipment, first aid kit, and insect repellent. For multi-day walks, you'll also need a reliable water filtration system, trekking poles for stability, and appropriate layers for changing weather conditions. I personally use the LifeStraw Personal Water Filter for reliable hydration on remote trails. Quality gear can make the difference between an amazing experience and a miserable one, so invest in reliable equipment from trusted brands.

When is the best time to do great walks?

The best time varies by location and personal preferences. New Zealand's Great Walks season runs October-April for alpine tracks, though some coastal walks like Abel Tasman and Heaphy are accessible year-round. International destinations vary significantly – the Inca Trail is best in dry season (May-September), while European walks are ideal in summer months. Consider weather patterns, crowd levels, and seasonal track closures when planning your adventure. I often prefer shoulder seasons for fewer crowds and more affordable accommodation, though weather can be less predictable.

How difficult are great walks for beginners?

Most great walks are designed for intermediate fitness levels, but several are suitable for beginners with proper preparation. New Zealand's Abel Tasman Coast Track and Lake Waikaremoana are gentler options with well-maintained paths and gradual elevation changes. The key is building fitness gradually over months, choosing appropriate walks for your experience level, and ensuring you have proper gear and planning. Start with shorter day hikes before attempting multi-day adventures. I always recommend consulting with local rangers or guide services about current track conditions and difficulty levels for your specific fitness and experience.

What's the difference between guided and self-guided great walks?

Self-guided walks offer more freedom and significantly lower costs but require detailed planning, carrying all your gear, and solid navigation skills. You'll need to arrange your own food, cooking equipment, and emergency preparedness. Guided walks provide expert local knowledge, prepared meals, comfortable accommodations, and reduced pack weight, but cost significantly more and follow fixed itineraries. Choose based on your experience level, budget, and preference for independence versus support. I prefer self-guided adventures for the freedom and challenge, but recommend guided options for first-time hikers or complex international destinations.

Pro Tips from the Trail

Conclusion

Great walks represent more than simple hiking experiences – they offer transformative journeys through some of Earth's most spectacular landscapes. Whether you choose New Zealand's world-renowned tracks, international destinations like Peru's Inca Trail, or hidden gems closer to home, each great walk provides opportunities for personal growth, natural connection, and unforgettable memories that last a lifetime.

Success on great walks depends on thorough preparation, quality equipment, and realistic expectations about your abilities and conditions. The planning process itself becomes part of the adventure, building anticipation and ensuring you're ready for whatever challenges and wonders await on the trail. Remember that flexibility and positive attitude often matter more than perfect gear or detailed itineraries.

My years of great walk experiences have taught me that these adventures offer far more value than their costs or efforts require. The friendships formed, personal challenges overcome, and natural beauty witnessed create lasting impacts that influence how we see ourselves and our place in the natural world. Every great walk teaches lessons applicable to life beyond the trail.

Start planning your great walk adventure today. Research destinations that match your interests and abilities, begin building fitness and gathering quality gear, and prepare for experiences that will enrich your life in unexpected ways. The trails are waiting, and each step forward brings new discoveries and personal growth.
